Informed proposals for local MCMC in discrete spaces

Giacomo Zanella
Abstract

There is a lack of methodological results to design efficient Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms for statistical models with discrete-valued high-dimensional parameters. Motivated by this consideration, we propose a simple framework for the design of informed MCMC proposals (i.e.Â Metropolis-Hastings proposal distributions that appropriately incorporate local information about the target) which is naturally applicable to both discrete and continuous spaces. We explicitly characterize the class of optimal proposal distributions under this framework, which we refer to as locally-balanced proposals, and prove their Peskun-optimality in high-dimensional regimes. The resulting algorithms are straightforward to implement in discrete spaces and provide orders of magnitude improvements in efficiency compared to alternative MCMC schemes, including discrete versions of Hamiltonian Monte Carlo. Simulations are performed with both simulated and real datasets, including a detailed application to Bayesian record linkage. A direct connection with gradient-based MCMC suggests that locally-balanced proposals may be seen as a natural way to extend the latter to discrete spaces.

1 Introduction

Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms are one the most widely used methodologies to sample from complex and intractable probability distributions, especially in the context of Bayesian statistics [Robert and Casella, 2005]. Given a distribution of interest Î â€‹(dâ€‹x)Î ğ‘‘ğ‘¥\Pi(dx) defined on some measurable space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, MCMC methods simulate a Markov chain {Xt}t=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1\{X_{t}\}_{t=1}^{\infty} having Î Î \Pi as stationary distribution and then use the states visited by Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t} as Monte Carlo samples from Î Î \Pi. Under mild assumptions, the Ergodic Theorem guarantees that the resulting sample averages are consistent estimators for arbitrary expectations under Î Î \Pi. Many MCMC schemes used in practice fall within the Metropolis-Hastings (MH) framework [Metropolis etÂ al., 1953, Hastings, 1970]. Given a current state xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X}, the MH algorithm samples a proposed state yğ‘¦y according to some proposal distribution Qâ€‹(x,â‹…)ğ‘„ğ‘¥â‹…Q(x,\cdot) and then accepts it with probability aâ€‹(x,y)=minâ¡{1,Î â€‹(dâ€‹y)â€‹Qâ€‹(y,dâ€‹x)Î â€‹(dâ€‹x)â€‹Qâ€‹(x,dâ€‹y)}ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦1Î ğ‘‘ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘‘ğ‘¥Î ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦a(x,y)=\min\left\{1,\frac{\Pi(dy)Q(y,dx)}{\Pi(dx)Q(x,dy)}\right\} or otherwise rejects it and stays at xğ‘¥x. The resulting transition kernel

Pâ€‹(x,dâ€‹y)=Qâ€‹(x,dâ€‹y)+Î´xâ€‹(dâ€‹y)â€‹âˆ«ğ’³(1âˆ’aâ€‹(x,z))â€‹Qâ€‹(x,dâ€‹z)ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ›¿ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ’³1ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘§ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘§P(x,dy)=Q(x,dy)+\delta_{x}(dy)\int_{\mathcal{X}}(1-a(x,z))Q(x,dz)

is Î Î \Pi-reversible and can be used for MCMC purposes. Although the MH algorithm can be applied to virtually any target distribution, its efficiency depends drastically on the proposal distribution Qğ‘„Q and its interaction with the target Î Î \Pi. Good choices of Qğ‘„Q will speed up the Markov chainâ€™s convergence while bad choices will slow it down in a potentially dramatic way.

1.1 Random walk versus informed schemes

Random walk MH schemes use symmetric proposal distributions satisfying Qâ€‹(x,y)=Qâ€‹(y,x)ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘¥Q(x,y)=Q(y,x), such as normal distributions centered at the current location QÏƒâ€‹(x,â‹…)=Nâ€‹(x,Ïƒ2â€‹ğ•€n)subscriptğ‘„ğœğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœ2subscriptğ•€ğ‘›Q_{\sigma}(x,\cdot)=N(x,\sigma^{2}\mathbb{I}_{n}). Although these schemes are easy to implement, the new state yğ‘¦y is proposed â€œblindlyâ€ (i.e.Â using no information about Î Î \Pi) and this can lead to bad mixing and slow convergence. In continuous frameworks, such as ğ’³=â„nğ’³superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{X}=\mathbb{R}^{n} and Î â€‹(dâ€‹x)=Ï€â€‹(x)â€‹dâ€‹xÎ ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¥\Pi(dx)=\pi(x)dx, various informed MH proposal distributions have been designed to obtain better convergence. For example the Metropolis-Adjusted Langevin Algorithm (MALA, e.g.Â Roberts and Rosenthal, 1998) exploits the gradient of the target to bias the proposal distribution towards high probability regions by setting QÏƒâ€‹(x,â‹…)=Nâ€‹(x+Ïƒ22â€‹âˆ‡(logâ¡Ï€)â¡(x),Ïƒ2â€‹ğ•€n)subscriptğ‘„ğœğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœ22âˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘¥superscriptğœ2subscriptğ•€ğ‘›Q_{\sigma}(x,\cdot)=N(x+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2}\nabla(\log\pi)(x),\sigma^{2}\mathbb{I}_{n}). Such an algorithm is derived by discretizing the Î Î \Pi-reversible Langevin diffusion Xtsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡X_{t} given by dâ€‹Xt=Ïƒ22â€‹âˆ‡(logâ¡Ï€)â¡(x)â€‹dâ€‹t+Ïƒâ€‹dâ€‹Btğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡superscriptğœ22âˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğœğ‘‘subscriptğµğ‘¡dX_{t}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2}\nabla(\log\pi)(x)dt+\sigma dB_{t}, so that the proposal QÏƒsubscriptğ‘„ğœQ_{\sigma} is approximately Î Î \Pi-reversible for small values of Ïƒğœ\sigma. More elaborate gradient-based informed proposals have been devised, such as Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC, e.g.Â Neal [2011], Girolami and Calderhead [2011]), and other schemes [Welling and Teh, 2011, Titsias and Papaspiliopoulos, 2016, Durmus etÂ al., 2017], resulting in substantial improvements of MCMC performances both in theory and in practice. However, most of these proposal distributions are derived as discretization of continuous-time diffusion processes or measure-preserving flows, and are based on derivatives and Gaussian distributions. Currently, it is not clear how to appropriately extend such methods to frameworks where ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} is a discrete space. As a consequence, practitioners using MCMC to target measures on discrete spaces often rely on symmetric/uninformed proposal distributions, which can induce slow convergence.

1.2 Informed proposals in discrete spaces

A simple way to circumvent the problem described above is to map discrete spaces to continuous ones and then apply informed schemes in the latter, typically using HMC [Zhang etÂ al., 2012, Pakman and Paninski, 2013, Nishimura etÂ al., 2017]. Although useful in some scenarios, the main limitation of this approach is that the embedding of discrete spaces into continuous ones is not always feasible and can potentially destroy the natural topological structure of the discrete space under consideration (e.g.Â spaces of trees, partitions, permutations,â€¦), thus resulting in highly multimodal and irregular target distributions that are hard to explore. An alternative approach was recently proposed in [Titsias and Yau, 2017], where informed proposals are obtained by introducing auxiliary variables and performing Gibbs Sampling in the augmented space. The resulting scheme, named the Hamming Ball sampler, requires no continuous space embedding and is directly applicable to generic discrete spaces, but the potentially strong correlation between the auxiliary variables and the chain state can severely slow down convergence.

In this work we formulate the problem of designing informed MH proposal distributions in an original way. Our formulation has the merit of being simple and unifying continuous and discrete frameworks. The theoretical results hint to a simple and practical class of informed MH proposal distributions that are well designed for high-dimensional discrete problems, which we refer to as locally-balanced proposals. Experiments on both simulated and real data show orders of magnitude improvements in efficiency compared to both random walk MH and the alternative informed schemes described above.

1.3 Paper structure

In Section 2 we define the class of informed proposals distribution considered (obtained as a product of some â€œbaseâ€ uninformed kernel and a biasing multiplicative term) and we characterize the class of biasing terms that are asymptotically-exact in the local limit regime (i.e.Â stepsize of the proposal going to 0). In Section 3 we show that, under regularity assumptions on the target, the same class of locally-balanced proposals is also optimal in terms of Peskun ordering as the dimensionality of the state space increases. In Section 4 we consider a simple binary target distribution in order to compare different locally-balanced proposals and identify the one leading to the smallest mixing time, which turns out to be related to the Barkerâ€™s algorithm [Barker, 1965]. Section 5 discusses the connection with classical gradient-based MCMC and MALA in particular. In Section 6 we perform simulation studies on classic discrete models (permutation spaces and Ising model), while in Section 7 we consider a more detailed application to Bayesian Record Linkage problems. Finally, in Section 8 we discuss possible extensions and future works. Supplementary material includes proofs and additional details on the simulations studies.

2.2 Definition and characterization of locally-balanced proposals

In this work we will consider a specific class of informed proposal distributions, which we refer to as pointwise informed proposals. These proposals have the following structure

Although the scheme in (2) is not the only way to design informed MH proposals, it is an interesting framework to consider. Definition 1.

(Locally-balanced kernels) A family of Markov transition kernels {QÏƒ}Ïƒ>0subscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğœğœ0\{Q_{\sigma}\}_{\sigma>0} is locally-balanced with respect to a distribution Î Î \Pi if each QÏƒsubscriptğ‘„ğœQ_{\sigma} is reversible with respect to some distribution Î ÏƒsubscriptÎ ğœ\Pi_{\sigma} such that Î ÏƒsubscriptÎ ğœ\Pi_{\sigma} converges weakly to Î Î \Pi as Ïƒâ†“0â†“ğœ0\sigma\downarrow 0.

The idea behind using a locally-balanced kernel QÏƒsubscriptğ‘„ğœQ_{\sigma} as a MH proposal targeting Î Î \Pi is that, in a local move regime (i.e. for small Ïƒğœ\sigma), QÏƒsubscriptğ‘„ğœQ_{\sigma} will be almost Î Î \Pi-reversible and therefore the Metropolis-Hastings correction will have less job to do (namely correcting for the difference between Î ÏƒsubscriptÎ ğœ\Pi_{\sigma} and Î Î \Pi). This would allow for more moves to be accepted and longer moves to be performed, thus improving the algorithmâ€™s efficiency. The reason to consider the local-move regime is that, as the dimensionality of the state space increases the MH moves typically become smaller and smaller with respect to the size of ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}. These heuristic ideas will be confirmed by theoretical results and simulations studies in the following sections. A pointwise informed proposal {Qg,Ïƒ}Ïƒ>0subscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘”ğœğœ0\{Q_{g,\sigma}\}_{\sigma>0} is locally-balanced with respect to a general Î Î \Pi if and only if

Motivated by Theorem 1 we refer to functions gğ‘”g satisfying (4) as balancing functions. In the next section we provide some results showing that locally-balanced proposals produce asymptotically more efficient MH algorithms compared to other pointwise informed proposals.

3 Peskun optimality of locally-balanced proposals

In this section we use Peskun ordering to compare the efficiency of Metropolis-Hastings (MH) schemes generated by pointwise informed proposals defined in (2). Unlike Section 2, where we considered the local limit Ïƒâ†“0â†“ğœ0\sigma\downarrow 0, we now consider a â€œfixed Ïƒğœ\sigmaâ€ scenario, dropping the Ïƒğœ\sigma subscript and denoting the base kernel and corresponding pointwise informed proposals by Kğ¾K and Qgsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘”Q_{g} respectively. We focus on discrete spaces, where Peskun-type results are more natural and broadly applicable. Thus we assume ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} to be a finite space and dâ€‹xğ‘‘ğ‘¥dx to be the counting measure, meaning that Ï€ğœ‹\pi is the probability mass function of Î Î \Pi and Kâ€‹(x,y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y) is a symmetric transition matrix.

3.1 Background on Peskun ordering

Peskun ordering provides a comparison result for Markov chains convergence properties. It measure the efficiency of MCMC algorithms in terms of asymptotic variance and spectral gap. The notion of asymptotic variance describes how the correlation among MCMC samples affects the variance of the empirical averages estimators. Given a Ï€ğœ‹\pi-stationary transition kernel Pğ‘ƒP and a function h:Î©â†’â„:â„â†’Î©â„h:\Omega\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, the asymptotic variance varÏ€â€‹(h,P)subscriptvarğœ‹â„ğ‘ƒ\hbox{var}_{\pi}(h,P) is defined as

varÏ€â€‹(h,P)=limTâ†’âˆTâ€‹varâ€‹(âˆ‘t=1Thâ€‹(Xt)T)=limTâ†’âˆTâˆ’1â€‹varâ€‹(âˆ‘t=1Thâ€‹(Xt)),subscriptvarğœ‹â„ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ†’ğ‘‡ğ‘‡varsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡â„subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptâ†’ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‡1varsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡â„subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡\hbox{var}_{\pi}(h,P)\;=\;\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}T\,\hbox{var}\left(\frac{\sum_{t=1}^{T}h(X_{t})}{T}\right)\;=\;\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}T^{-1}\,\hbox{var}\left(\sum_{t=1}^{T}h(X_{t})\right)\;,

where X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1}, X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2}, â€¦is a Markov chain with transition kernel Pğ‘ƒP started in stationarity (i.e.Â with X1âˆ¼Ï€similar-tosubscriptğ‘‹1ğœ‹X_{1}\sim\pi) . The smaller varÏ€â€‹(h,P)subscriptvarğœ‹â„ğ‘ƒ\hbox{var}_{\pi}(h,P) the more efficient the corresponding MCMC algorithm is in estimating ğ”¼Ï€â€‹[h]subscriptğ”¼ğœ‹delimited-[]â„\mathbb{E}_{\pi}[h]. The spectral gap of a Markov transition kernel Pğ‘ƒP is defined as Gâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹(P)=1âˆ’Î»2ğºğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒ1subscriptğœ†2Gap(P)=1-\lambda_{2}, where Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} is the second largest eigenvalue of Pğ‘ƒP, and always satisfy Gâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹(P)â‰¥0ğºğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒ0Gap(P)\geq 0. The value of Gâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹(P)ğºğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒGap(P) is closely related to the convergence properties of Pğ‘ƒP, with values close to 0 corresponding to slow convergence and values distant from 0 corresponding to fast convergence (see, e.g., [Levin etÂ al., 2009, Ch.12-13] for a review of spectral theory for discrete Markov chains).

Theorem 2.

Theorem 2 implies that if P1â€‹(x,y)â‰¥câ€‹P2â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ‘ƒ2ğ‘¥ğ‘¦P_{1}(x,y)\geq c\,P_{2}(x,y) for all xâ‰ yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\neq y, then P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} is â€œcğ‘c times more efficientâ€ than P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} in terms of spectral gap and asymptotic variances (ignoring the varÏ€â€‹(h)subscriptvarğœ‹â„\hbox{var}_{\pi}(h) term which is typically much smaller than varÏ€â€‹(h,P2)subscriptvarğœ‹â„subscriptğ‘ƒ2\hbox{var}_{\pi}(h,P_{2}) in non-trivial applications).

4 Optimal choice of balancing function

In Section 3 we showed that, under the regularity assumption (A), locally-balanced proposals are asymptotically optimal in terms of Peskun ordering. It is thus natural to ask if there is an optimal proposal among the locally-balanced ones or, equivalently, if there is an optimal balancing function gğ‘”g among the ones satisfying gâ€‹(t)=tâ€‹gâ€‹(1/t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘”1ğ‘¡g(t)=tg(1/t) (see Table 1). Before answering this question, we first draw a connection between the choice of balancing function gğ‘”g and the choice of acceptance probability function in the accept/reject step of the Metropolis-Hastings (MH) algorithm.

4.1 Connection between balancing functions and acceptance probability functions.

The MH algorithm accepts each proposed state yğ‘¦y with some probability aâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦a(x,y) which we refer to as acceptance probability function (APF). Denoting the ratio Ï€â€‹(y)â€‹Qâ€‹(y,x)Ï€â€‹(x)â€‹Qâ€‹(x,y)ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\frac{\pi(y)Q(y,x)}{\pi(x)Q(x,y)} by tâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦t(x,y), the Metropolis-Hastings APF can be written as aâ€‹(x,y)=gâ€‹(tâ€‹(x,y))ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦a(x,y)=g(t(x,y)) with gâ€‹(t)=1âˆ§tğ‘”ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡g(t)=1\wedge t. It is well known that this is not the only possible choice: as long as

aâ€‹(x,y)=tâ€‹(x,y)â€‹aâ€‹(y,x)âˆ€x,y:Qâ€‹(x,y)>0,:ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘¥for-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0\hskip 56.9055pta(x,y)=t(x,y)\,a(y,x)\qquad\forall x,y:\,Q(x,y)>0\,, (11)

the resulting kernel Pğ‘ƒP is Ï€ğœ‹\pi-reversible and can be used for MCMC purposes. If we write aâ€‹(x,y)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦a(x,y) as gâ€‹(tâ€‹(x,y))ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦g(t(x,y)), condition (11) translates to

gâ€‹(t)=tâ€‹gâ€‹(1/t).ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘”1ğ‘¡g(t)=tg(1/t)\,.

The latter coincides with the condition for gğ‘”g to be a balancing function, see Theorem 1. Therefore each APF aâ€‹(x,y)=gâ€‹(tâ€‹(x,y))ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦a(x,y)=g(t(x,y)) corresponds to a balancing function gğ‘”g. However, the family of balancing functions is broader than the family of APFs because aâ€‹(x,y)=gâ€‹(tâ€‹(x,y))ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¦a(x,y)=g(t(x,y)) are probabilities and thus need to be bounded by 1, while balancing functions donâ€™t. For example, gâ€‹(t)=tğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡g(t)=\sqrt{t} or 1âˆ¨t1ğ‘¡1\vee t are valid balancing functions but are not upper bounded by 1 and thus they are not a valid APF.

The connection with APFs is interesting because the latter are classical and well studied objects. In particular it is well-known that, in the context of APFs, the Metropolis-Hastings choice gâ€‹(t)=1âˆ§tğ‘”ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡g(t)=1\wedge t is optimal and Peskun-dominates all other choices [Peskun, 1973, Tierney, 1998]. This fact, however, does not translate to the context of balancing functions. In the latter case the comparison between different gğ‘”gâ€™s is more subtle and we expect no choice of balancing function to Peskun-dominate the others in general, not even asymptotically. In the next section we study a simple scenario and show that, in that case, the optimal balancing function is given by gâ€‹(t)=t1+tğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡g(t)=\frac{t}{1+t}. Interestingly, the latter choice leads to a natural balancing term gâ€‹(Ï€â€‹(y)Ï€â€‹(x))=Ï€â€‹(y)Ï€â€‹(x)+Ï€â€‹(y)ğ‘”ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘¦g(\frac{\pi(y)}{\pi(x)})=\frac{\pi(y)}{\pi(x)+\pi(y)}, which has been previously considered in the context of APFs and is commonly referred to as Barker choice [Barker, 1965].

4.2 The optimal proposal for independent binary variables

In this section we compare the efficiency of different locally-balanced proposals in the independent binary components case of Example 1. It turns out that in this specific case the Barker balancing function gâ€‹(t)=t1+tğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡g(t)=\frac{t}{1+t} leads to the smallest mixing time.

From Example 1, each move from x1:nsubscriptx:1ğ‘›\textbf{x}_{1:n} to a neighbouring state y1:nâˆˆNâ€‹(x1:n)subscripty:1ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptx:1ğ‘›\textbf{y}_{1:n}\in N(\textbf{x}_{1:n}) is obtained by flipping one component of x1:nsubscriptx:1ğ‘›\textbf{x}_{1:n}, say the iğ‘–i-th bit, either from 00 to 111 or from 111 to 00. We denote the former by y1:n=x1:n+e1:n(i)subscripty:1ğ‘›subscriptx:1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscripteğ‘–:1ğ‘›\textbf{y}_{1:n}=\textbf{x}_{1:n}+\textbf{e}^{(i)}_{1:n} and the latter by y1:n=x1:nâˆ’e1:n(i)subscripty:1ğ‘›subscriptx:1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscripteğ‘–:1ğ‘›\textbf{y}_{1:n}=\textbf{x}_{1:n}-\textbf{e}^{(i)}_{1:n}. Qg(n)â€‹(x1:n,y1:n)=1Zg(n)â€‹(x1:n)â€‹{gâ€‹(pi1âˆ’pi)ifÂ y1:n=x1:n+e1:n(i),gâ€‹(1âˆ’pipi)ifÂ y1:n=x1:nâˆ’e1:n(i),0ifÂ y1:nâˆ‰Nâ€‹(x1:n).subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘”subscriptx:1ğ‘›subscripty:1ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘›subscriptx:1ğ‘›casesğ‘”subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptifÂ y:1ğ‘›subscriptx:1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscripteğ‘–:1ğ‘›ğ‘”1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptifÂ y:1ğ‘›subscriptx:1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscripteğ‘–:1ğ‘›0subscriptifÂ y:1ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptx:1ğ‘›Q^{(n)}_{g}(\textbf{x}_{1:n},\textbf{y}_{1:n})=\frac{1}{Z_{g}^{(n)}(\textbf{x}_{1:n})}\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}g(\frac{p_{i}}{1-p_{i}})&\hbox{if }\textbf{y}_{1:n}=\textbf{x}_{1:n}+\textbf{e}^{(i)}_{1:n}\,,\\ g(\frac{1-p_{i}}{p_{i}})&\hbox{if }\textbf{y}_{1:n}=\textbf{x}_{1:n}-\textbf{e}^{(i)}_{1:n}\,,\\ 0&\hbox{if }\textbf{y}_{1:n}\notin N\big{(}\textbf{x}_{1:n}\big{)}\,.\end{array}\right. (12)

In order to compare the efficiency of Qg(n)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„ğ‘›ğ‘”Q^{(n)}_{g} for different choices of gğ‘”g we proceed in two steps. First we show that, after appropriate time-rescaling, the Metropolis-Hastings chain of interest converges to a tractable continuous time process as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty (Theorem 4). Secondly we find which choice of gğ‘”g induces the fastest mixing on the limiting continuous-time process. 5 Connection to MALA and gradient-based MCMC

In the context of continuous state spaces, such as ğ’³=â„nğ’³superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{X}=\mathbb{R}^{n}, it is typically not feasible to sample efficiently from pointwise informed proposals as defined in (2). A natural thing to do in this context is to replace the intractable term in gâ€‹(Ï€â€‹(y)Ï€â€‹(x))ğ‘”ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¥g(\frac{\pi(y)}{\pi(x)}), i.e.Â the target Ï€â€‹(y)ğœ‹ğ‘¦\pi(y), with some local approximation around the current location xğ‘¥x. For example, using a first-order Taylor expansion elogâ¡Ï€â€‹(y)â‰ˆelogâ¡Ï€â€‹(x)+âˆ‡logâ¡Ï€â€‹(x)â‹…(yâˆ’x)superscriptğ‘’ğœ‹ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘’ğœ‹ğ‘¥â‹…âˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥e^{\log\pi(y)}\approx e^{\log\pi(x)+\nabla\log\pi(x)\cdot(y-x)} we obtain a family of first-order informed proposals of the form

Qg,Ïƒ(1)â€‹(x,dâ€‹y)âˆgâ€‹(eâˆ‡logâ¡Ï€â€‹(x)â‹…(yâˆ’x))â€‹KÏƒâ€‹(x,dâ€‹y),superscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘”ğœ1ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦proportional-toğ‘”superscriptğ‘’â‹…âˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ¾ğœğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘¦Q_{g,\sigma}^{(1)}(x,dy)\quad\propto\quad g\left(e^{\nabla\log\pi(x)\cdot(y-x)}\right)K_{\sigma}(x,dy)\,, (17)

for KÏƒsubscriptğ¾ğœK_{\sigma} symmetric and gğ‘”g satisfying (4). Interestingly, the well known MALA proposal (e.g.Â Roberts and Rosenthal, 1998) can be obtained from (17) by choosing gâ€‹(t)=tğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡g(t)=\sqrt{t} and a gaussian kernel KÏƒâ€‹(x,â‹…)=Nâ€‹(x,Ïƒ2)subscriptğ¾ğœğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘ğ‘¥superscriptğœ2K_{\sigma}(x,\cdot)=N(x,\sigma^{2}). Therefore we can think at MALA as a specific instance of locally-balanced proposal with first-order Taylor approximation. This simple and natural connection between locally-balanced proposals and classical gradient based schemes hints to many possible extentions of the latter, such as modifying the balancing function gğ‘”g or kernel KÏƒsubscriptğ¾ğœK_{\sigma} or considering a different approximation for Ï€â€‹(y)ğœ‹ğ‘¦\pi(y). The flexibility of the resulting framework could help to increase the robustness and efficiency of gradient-based methods. Recently, Titsias and Papaspiliopoulos [2016] considered different but related approaches to generalize gradient-based MCMC schemes, achieving state of the art sampling algorithms for various applications compared to both MALA and HMC. Given the focus of this paper on discrete spaces, we do not pursue this avenue here, leaving this research lines to future work (see Section 8).

6 Simulation studies

In this section we perform simulation studies using the target distributions of Examples 2 and 3. All computations are performed using the Rğ‘…R programming language with code freely available upon request. The aim of the simulation study is two-folded: first comparing informed schemes with random walk ones, and secondly comparing different constructions of informed schemes among themselves.

6.1 MCMC schemes under consideration

We compare six schemes: random walk MH (RW), a globally-balanced proposal (GB), two locally-balanced proposals (LB1 and LB2), the Hamming Ball sampler (HB) proposed in [Titsias and Yau, 2017] and the discrete HMC algorithm (D-HMC) proposed in Pakman and Paninski [2013]. The first four schemes (RW-GB-LB1-LB2) are Metropolis-Hastings algorithms with pointwise informed proposals of the form Qgâ€‹(x,y)âˆgâ€‹(Ï€â€‹(y)Ï€â€‹(x))â€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)proportional-tosubscriptğ‘„ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘”ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Q_{g}(x,y)\propto g\left(\frac{\pi(y)}{\pi(x)}\right)K(x,y), with gâ€‹(t)ğ‘”ğ‘¡g(t) equal to 111, tğ‘¡t, tğ‘¡\sqrt{t} and t1+tğ‘¡1ğ‘¡\frac{t}{1+t} respectively. HB is a data augmentation scheme that, given the current location xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}, first samples an auxiliary variable uâˆ¼Kâ€‹(xt,â‹…)similar-toğ‘¢ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡â‹…u\sim K(x_{t},\cdot) and then samples the new state xt+1âˆ¼QÏ€â€‹(u,â‹…)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘¢â‹…x_{t+1}\sim Q_{\pi}(u,\cdot), where QÏ€â€‹(u,y)âˆÏ€â€‹(y)â€‹Kâ€‹(u,y)proportional-tosubscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘¢ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¢ğ‘¦Q_{\pi}(u,y)\propto\pi(y)K(u,y) is defined as in (1). No acceptance-reject step is required as the chain is already Ï€ğœ‹\pi-reversible, being interpretable as a two stage Gibbs sampler on the extended state space (x,u)ğ‘¥ğ‘¢(x,u) with target Ï€â€‹(x)â€‹Kâ€‹(x,u)ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¢\pi(x)K(x,u). To have a fair comparison, all these five schemes use the same base kernel Kğ¾K, defined as Kâ€‹(x,â‹…)=Uâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹fâ€‹(Nâ€‹(x))ğ¾ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘ˆğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¥K(x,\cdot)=Unif(N(x)) with neighbouring structures {Nâ€‹(x)}xâˆˆğ’³subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ’³\{N(x)\}_{x\in\mathcal{X}} defined in Examples 2 and 3. Finally, D-HMC is a sampler specific to binary target distributions (thus applicable to Example 3 but not to Examples 2) constructed by first embedding the binary space in a continuous space and then applying HMC in the latter. For its implementation we followed Pakman and Paninski [2013], using a Gaussian distribution for the momentum variables and an integration time equal to 2.5â€‹Ï€2.5ğœ‹2.5\pi. We will be talking about acceptance rates for all schemes, even if HB and D-HMC are not constructed as MH schemes. For HB, we define the acceptance rate as the proportion of times that the new state xt+1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1x_{t+1} is different from the previous state xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} (indeed the sampling procedure uâˆ¼Kâ€‹(xt,â‹…)similar-toğ‘¢ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡â‹…u\sim K(x_{t},\cdot) and xt+1âˆ¼QÏ€â€‹(u,â‹…)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘„ğœ‹ğ‘¢â‹…x_{t+1}\sim Q_{\pi}(u,\cdot) does often return xt+1=xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t+1}=x_{t}). For D-HMC we define the acceptance rate as the proportion of times that a proposal to flip a binary component in the HMC flow is accepted (using the Pakman and Paninski [2013] terminology, the proportion of times that the particle crosses a potentiall wall rather than bouncing back). Such definitions will facilitate comparison with MH schemes.

6.2 Sampling permutations

Consider the setting of Example 2, with target density Ï€(n)â€‹(Ï)âˆâˆi=1nwiâ€‹Ïâ€‹(i)proportional-tosuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘›ğœŒsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğœŒğ‘–\pi^{(n)}(\rho)\propto\prod_{i=1}^{n}w_{i\rho(i)} defined in (7) and base kernel Kâ€‹(Ï,â‹…)ğ¾ğœŒâ‹…K(\rho,\cdot) being the uniform distribution on the neighborhood Nâ€‹(Ï)ğ‘ğœŒN(\rho) defined in (8). The distribution Ï€(n)superscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi^{(n)} arises in many applied scenarios (e.g.Â Dellaert etÂ al., 2003, Oh etÂ al., 2009, Zanella, 2015) and sampling from the latter is a non-trivial task that is often accomplished with MCMC algorithms (see e.g.Â Jerrum and Sinclair [1996] for related complexity results).

For our simulations we first consider the case of i.i.d.Â weights {wiâ€‹j}i,j=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›\{w_{ij}\}_{i,j=1}^{n} with logâ¡(wiâ€‹j)âˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,Î»2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘0superscriptğœ†2\log(w_{ij})\sim N(0,\lambda^{2}). Here nğ‘›n and Î»ğœ†\lambda provide control on the dimensionality and the smoothness of the target distribution respectively. For example, when Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 the target distribution is uniform and the five schemes under consideration (D-HMC not applicable) collapse to the same transition kernel, which is Kâ€‹(Ï,â‹…)ğ¾ğœŒâ‹…K(\rho,\cdot) itself (modulo HB performing two steps per iteration). On the other hand, as Î»ğœ†\lambda increases the difference between RW and informed schemes becomes more prominent (Figure 1).

In fact, for â€œroughâ€ distributions, most states proposed by RW have small probability under the target and get rejected. Despite being more robust than RW, also GB and HB suffer from high rejection rates as Î»ğœ†\lambda increase. On the contrary, the acceptance rates of LB1 and LB2, which are designed to be asymptotically Ï€ğœ‹\pi-reversible, approaches 1 as nğ‘›n increases for all values of Î»ğœ†\lambda considered (Figure 1, first row). In order to take into account the cost per iteration, which is substantially higher for informed schemes, we then compare the number of successful â€œflipsâ€ (i.e.Â switches of two indices) per unit of computation time. The latter is a useful and easy to estimate diagnostic that provides a first gross indication of the relative efficiency of the various schemes. Figure 1 suggests that for flatter targets (i.e.Â small values of Î»ğœ†\lambda) the computational overhead required to use informed proposal schemes is not worth the effort, as a plain RW proposal achieves the highest number of flips per unit time. However, as the roughness increases and the target distribution becomes more challenging to explore, informed proposals (in particular LB1 and LB2) achieve a much higher number of flips per unit time. Similar conclusions are obtained by using more advanced diagnostic tools, such as effective sample size per unit time. For example, Figure 2 displays the results for n=500ğ‘›500n=500 and Î»=5ğœ†5\lambda=5, suggesting that for rough targets locally-balanced schemes are are one to two orders of magnitude more efficient than the other schemes under consideration (see Supplement B.1 for results for all values of Î»ğœ†\lambda).

Note that GB is extremely sensitive to the starting state: if the latter is unlikely under the target (e.g.Â a uniformly at random permutation) the chain gets stuck and reject almost all moves, while if started in stationarity (i.e. from a permutation approx.Â drawn from the target) the chain has a more stable behaviour (see Figure 2).

Finally, consider a more structured case where, rather than iid weights, we sample wiâ€‹jâˆ¼expâ¡(âˆ’Ï‡|iâˆ’j|2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2ğ‘–ğ‘—w_{ij}\sim\exp(-\chi^{2}_{|i-j|}).

The resulting matrix {wiâ€‹j}i,j=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›\{w_{ij}\}_{i,j=1}^{n} has a banded-like structure, with weights getting smaller with distance from the diagonal. Figure 3 shows the performances of the different schemes. The results are similar to the iid case, with an even more prominent difference in efficiency between HB and LB1-LB2.

6.3 Ising model

Consider now the Ising model described in Example 3. The latter is a classic model used in many scientific areas, e.g.Â statistical mechanics and spatial statistics. In this simulation study we consider target distributions motivated by Bayesian image analysis, where one seeks to partition an image into objects and background. In the simplest version of the problem, each pixel iğ‘–i needs to be classified as object (xi=1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{i}=1) or background (xi=âˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{i}=-1). One approach to such task is to define a Bayesian model, using the Ising model (or the Potts model in more general multi-objects contexts) as a prior distribution to induce positive correlation among neighboring pixels. The resulting posterior distribution is made of a prior term expâ¡(Î»â€‹âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆEnxiâ€‹xj)ğœ†subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\exp(\lambda\sum_{(i,j)\in E_{n}}x_{i}x_{j}) times a likelihood term expâ¡(âˆ‘iâˆˆVnÎ±iâ€‹xi)subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\exp(\sum_{i\in V_{n}}\alpha_{i}x_{i}), which combined produce a distribution of the form (9). See Supplement B.2 for more details on the derivation of such distributions and Moores etÂ al. [2015a] for recent applications to computed tomography.

Similarly to Section 6.2, we considered an array of target distributions, varying the size of the nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n grid and the concentration of the target distribution (controlled by the strength of spatial correlation Î»ğœ†\lambda and signal-to-noise ratio in the likelihood terms Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i}). Figure 4 reports the acceptance rates and number of flips per unit of computing time for the six MCMC schemes under consideration and for five levels of target concentration (see Supplement B.2 for full details on the set up for Î»ğœ†\lambda and the Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i}â€™s). RW, GB and D-HMC have very low acceptance rates for all non-uniform distributions considered (see the Appendix of Pakman and Paninski [2013] for discussion on the similar acceptance rates between RW and D-HMC). HB, LB1 and LB2 on the contrary do not suffer from high rejection rates and achieve a much higher number of flips per unit time. However, despite having a good number of flips per second, HB suffers from poor mixing in most cases considered (see e.g.Â Figure 5 and Supplement B.2 for more examples). In summary, the results are similar to Section 6.2, with locally balanced schemes (LB1 and LB2) being orders of magnitude more efficient than alternative schemes especially when targeting highly non-uniform targets (see effective sample sizes per unit time in Figure 5 and Supplement B.2).

Given the focus of this work, we do not considered specialized algorithms for the Ising model performing global updates (e.g.Â Swendsen and Wang [1987]). The latter are somehow complementary to the single-site updating schemes considered here as they perform much better when the target is multimodal (e.g.Â in the absence of informative likelihood terms and with moderately strong interaction term Î»ğœ†\lambda), while they perform poorly in cases where the likelihood terms {Î±i}iâˆˆVnsubscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›\{\alpha_{i}\}_{i\in V_{n}} dominate, like the image analysis context considered here (see see e.g.Â Hurn [1997] and Moores etÂ al. [2015b] for more discussion).

6.4 Block-wise implementation

In many scenarios, as the dimensionality of the state space increases, also the computational cost of sampling from the pointwise informed proposals as defined in (2) increases. For example, in discrete space settings it is typical to have a base kernel Kâ€‹(x,â‹…)ğ¾ğ‘¥â‹…K(x,\cdot) which is a uniform distribution on some neighborhood Nâ€‹(x)âŠ†ğ’³ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ’³N(x)\subseteq\mathcal{X} whose size grows with the dimensionality of ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}. In these cases, when the size of Nâ€‹(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥N(x) becomes too large, it may be inefficient to use an informed proposal on the whole neighborhood Nâ€‹(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥N(x). Rather, it may be more efficient to first select a sub-neighborhood Nâ€²â€‹(x)âŠ†Nâ€‹(x)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥N^{\prime}(x)\subseteq N(x) at random, and then apply locally-balanced proposals to the selected subspace. For example, if the state space under consideration has a Cartesian product structure, then one could update a subset of variables given the others in a block-wise fashion, analogously to the Gibbs Sampling context. By choosing appropriately the size of Nâ€²â€‹(x)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥N^{\prime}(x) one can obtain an appropriate trade-off between computational cost (a small Nâ€²â€‹(x)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥N^{\prime}(x) induces an informed proposal that is cheap to sample) and statistical efficiency (a large Nâ€²â€‹(x)superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥N^{\prime}(x) produces better infomed moves as it considers more candidate states at each step). Such an approach is illustrated in Section 7 and Supplement C.4 on a record linkage application. See also Titsias and Yau [2017] for additional discussion on block-wise implementations and the resulting cost-vs-efficiency tradeoff in the context of the Hamming Ball sampler and Section 8 for related comments in future works discussion.

7 Application to Bayesian record linkage

Record linkage, also known as entity resolution, is the process of identifying which records refer to the same entity across two or more databases with potentially repeated entries. Such operation is typically performed to remove duplicates when merging different databases. If records are potentially noisy and unique identifiers are not available, statistical methods are needed to perform reliable record linkage operations. While traditional record linkage methodologies are based on the early work Fellegi and Sunter [1969], Bayesian approaches to record linkage are receiving increasing attention in recent years [Tancredi etÂ al., 2011, Steorts etÂ al., 2016, Sadinle, 2017, Johndrow etÂ al., 2017]. Such approaches are particularly interesting, for example, as they provide uncertainty statements on the linkage procedure that can be naturally propagated to subsequent inferences, such as population-size estimation [Tancredi etÂ al., 2011]. Despite recent advances in Bayesian modeling for record linkage problems (see e.g.Â Zanella etÂ al. [2016]), exploring the posterior distribution over the space of possible linkage configurations is still a computationally challenging task which is limiting the applicability of Bayesian record linkage methodologies. In this section we use locally-balanced proposals to derive efficient samplers for Bayesian record linkage.

We consider bipartite record linkage tasks, where one seeks to merge two databases with duplicates occurring across databases but not within. This is the most commonly considered case in the record linkage literature (see Sadinle [2017] and references therein). Denote by x=(x1,â€¦,xn1)xsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1\textbf{x}=(x_{1},\dots,x_{n_{1}}) and y=(y1,â€¦,yn2)ysubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ‘›2\textbf{y}=(y_{1},\dots,y_{n_{2}}) the two databases under consideration. In this context, the parameter of interest is a partial matching between {1,â€¦,n1}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›1\{1,\dots,n_{1}\} and {1,â€¦,n2}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›2\{1,\dots,n_{2}\}, where iğ‘–i is matched with jğ‘—j if and only if xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} and yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j} represent the same entity. We represent such a matching with a n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1}-dimensional vector M=(M1,â€¦,Mn1)Msubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘›1\textbf{M}=(M_{1},\dots,M_{n_{1}}), where Mi=jsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—M_{i}=j if xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is matched with yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j} and Mi=0subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–0M_{i}=0 if xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is not matched with any yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j}. In Supplement C we specify a Bayesian model for bipartite record linkage, assuming the number of entities and the number of duplicates to follow Poisson distributions a priori, and assuming the joint distribution of (x,y)xy(\textbf{x},\textbf{y}) given M to follow a spike-and-slab categorical distribution (often called hit-miss model in the Record Linkage literature [Copas and Hilton, 1990]). The unknown parameters of the model are the partial matching M and two real-valued hyperparameters Î»ğœ†\lambda and pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„p_{match}, representing the expected number of entities and the probability of having a duplicate for each entity. We perform inferences in a Metropolis-within-Gibbs fashion, where we alternate sampling (pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h,Î»)|Mconditionalsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„ğœ†M(p_{match},\lambda)|\textbf{M} and M|(pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h,Î»)conditionalMsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„ğœ†\textbf{M}|(p_{match},\lambda), see Supplement C.3 for full details on the sampler. While it is straightforward to sample from the two-dimensional distribution (pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h,Î»)|Mconditionalsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„ğœ†M(p_{match},\lambda)|\textbf{M}, see (42)-(43) in Supplement C for explicit full conditionals, providing an efficient way to update the high-dimensional discrete object M is more challenging and this is where we exploit locally-balanced proposals.

We consider a dataset derived from the Italian Survey on Household and Wealth, which is a biennial survey conducted by the Bank of Italy. The dataset is publicy available (e.g. through the Iâ€‹tâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹yğ¼ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘¦Italy R package) and consists of two databases, the 2008 survey (covering 13,702 individuals) and the 2010 one (covering 13,733 individuals). For each individual, the survey recorded 11 variables, such as year of birth, sex and working status.

First, following Steorts [2015], we perform record linkage for each Italian region separately. This results in 20 separate record linkage tasks with roughly 1300 individuals each on average. We ran four MCMC schemes for each record linkage task and compare their performances. Following the notation of Section 6, the four schemes are RW, GB, LB and HB, where LB refers to the locally-balanced proposals with Barker weights. Figure 6(a) shows the number of matches over MCMC iterations for region 1 (other regions show a similar qualitative behaviour). We can see that LB and HB converge rapidly to the region of substantial posterior probability, while RW and GB exhibit an extremely slow convergence. HB, however, converges and mixes significantly slower than LB (see e.g. the autocorrelation functions in 6(b)).

To provide a quantitative comparison between the performances of the four schemes, we consider as efficiency measure the effective sample sizes per unit of computation time relative to RW. Effective sample sizes are computed using the coda R package [Plummer etÂ al., 2006] and averaged over 5 summary statistics (each summary statistics being the Hamming distance from a matching randomly drawn from the posterior). From Table 2 we can see that LB provides roughly two orders of magnitude improvement in efficiency over RW and GB and one order of magnitude improvement over HB.

Indeed from Figure 6(c) we can see that, given the same computational budget, LB manages to provide much more reliable estimates of the posterior probabilities of each couple being matched compared to HB. Computations were performed using the Rğ‘…R programming language. For each region we ran LB for 350003500035000 iterations (enough to produce reliable estimates of posterior pairwise matching probabilities like the one in Figure 6(c)), requiring on average around 120 seconds per region.

Next, we consider the task of performing recording linkage on the whole Italy dataset, without dividing it first into regions. In fact the latter operation (typically referred to as deterministic blocking in the record linkage literature) is typically done for computational reasons but has the drawback of excluding a priori possible matches across groups (in this case regions). We apply LB to the whole dataset using the block-wise implementation discussed in Section 6.4 (details in Supplement C.4). Standard output analysis suggests that the LB chain is converging fast (Figure 7, left) and mixing well in the region of substantial probability (Figure 7, center).

Comparing independent runs of the algorithms suggests that we are obtaining reliable estimates of the nearly one billion posterior pairwise matching probabilities (Figure 7, right). The simulation needed to obtain the probability estimates in Figure 7(right) took less than 40 minutes with a plain Rğ‘…R implementation on a single desktop computer.

8 Discussion and future work

In this work we discussed a fundamental and yet not satisfactorily answered question in the MCMC methodology literature, which is how to design â€œinformedâ€ Metropolis-Hastings proposals in discrete spaces. We proposed a simple and original framework (pointwise informed proposals and locally-balanced criteria) that provides useful and easy-to-implement methodological guidance. Under regularity assumptions, we were able to prove the optimality of locally-balanced proposals in high-dimensional regimes and to identify the optimal elements within such class. The theoretical results of Sections 2-4 are confirmed by simulations (Sections 6-7), where we observe orders of magnitude improvements in efficiency over alternative schemes both for simulated and real data scenarios. We envisage that locally-balanced proposals could be helpful in various contexts to be incorporated as a building block in more elaborate Monte Carlo algorithms. The proposed methodology can be applied to arbitrary statistical models with discrete-valued parameters, such as Bayesian Nonparametric models or model selection problems.

The present work offers many directions for possible extentions and future work. For example, the connection to MALA in Section 5 could be exploited to improve the robustness of gradient-based MCMC schemes and reduce the notoriously heavy burden associated with their tuning procedures. Also, it would be interesting to extend our study to the popular context of Multiple-Try Metropolis (MTM) schemes [Liu etÂ al., 2000]. In fact, the MTM weight function, used to select the proposed point among candidate ones, plays a role that is very similar to one of multiplicative biasing terms in pointwise informed proposals and we expect our results to translate quite naturally to that context.

In terms of implementation, it would be interesting to explore in more depth the trade-off between computational cost per iteration and statistical efficiency of the resulting Markov chain. Beyond the use of block-wise implementations discussed in Section 6.4, another approach to reduce the cost per iteration would be to replace the informed term gâ€‹(Ï€â€‹(y)Ï€â€‹(x))ğ‘”ğœ‹ğ‘¦ğœ‹ğ‘¥g(\frac{\pi(y)}{\pi(x)}) in the proposal with some cheap-to-evaluate approximation, while still using the exact target in the MH accept/reject step. Also, the computations required to sample from locally-balanced proposals are trivially parallelizable and specific hardware for parallel computations, such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), could be used to reduce the computational overhead required by using informed proposals [Lee etÂ al., 2010].

From the theoretical point of view, it would be interesting to provide guidance for a regime which is intermediate between local and global, maybe by designing appropriate interpolations between locally-balanced and globally-balanced proposals. This could be useful to design schemes that adaptively learn the appropriate level of interpolation needed. Also, one could prove the sufficient condition for optimality (A) in much more general contexts. Finally, throughout the paper we assumed the base kernel KÏƒsubscriptğ¾ğœK_{\sigma} to be symmetric and it would be interesting to extend the results to the case of general base kernels.

A.4 Proof of Proposition 1

A.5.1 Some references for mixing time of product chains

For each kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}, S1:ksubscriptğ‘†:1ğ‘˜S_{1:k} is a continuous time Markov chain with independent components. Such chains are often called product chains and received considerable attention, for example in the context of the cutoff phenomenon (see e.g. Diaconis and Saloff-Coste [1996, Thm.2.9] or Levin etÂ al. [2009, Ch.20.4] and references therein). In particular Levin etÂ al. [2009, Thm.20.7], Barrera etÂ al. [2006, Prop. 7] and Bon and PÄƒltÄƒnea [2001, Cor. 4.3] provide results concerning the mixing time of {S1:k}k=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘†:1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1\{S_{1:k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty}. Such results tell us that, in the case of a sequence of independent binary Markov processes like {S1:k}k=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘†:1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1\{S_{1:k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty}, the asymptotic mixing time depends on the flipping rates of the worst components (provided they are a non-negligible quantity), and in particular in our case the mixing time is minimized by maximizing the quantity ZÂ¯â€‹(v)âˆ’1â€‹lim infiâ†’âˆviÂ¯ğ‘superscriptv1subscriptlimit-infimumâ†’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–\bar{Z}(\textbf{v})^{-1}\liminf_{i\rightarrow\infty}v_{i} (see Theorem 4 for the definition of ZÂ¯â€‹(v)Â¯ğ‘v\bar{Z}(\textbf{v}) and Barrera etÂ al. [2006] and Bon and PÄƒltÄƒnea [2001] for the precise assumptions on the flipping rates). It can be seen that the latter quantity is maximized by choosing visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} to be constant over iğ‘–i, meaning vi=vÂ¯subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘£v_{i}=\bar{v} for any iâˆˆâ„•ğ‘–â„•i\in\mathbb{N} for some vÂ¯>0Â¯ğ‘£0\bar{v}>0.

B.1 Supplement to Section 6.2

Figure 8 provides additional tracepots, acceptance rates and effective sample sizes related to the simulation study in Section 6.2.

Considering effective sample sizes per unit of computation time as measure of efficiency, it can be seen that the uninformed RW proposal performs best for flatter targets (i.e.Â small values of Î»ğœ†\lambda), while as the roughness of the target increases (i.e.Â larger values of Î»ğœ†\lambda) locally-balanced schemes strongly outperforms other schemes under consideration. Appendix C Supplement for the Record Linkage application

In this Supplement we describe in more details the Bayesian model for record linkage used in Section 7. The prior distribution follows mostly Miller etÂ al. [2015] and Zanella etÂ al. [2016], while the likelihood distribution is similar to, e.g.â€‰ Copas and Hilton [1990] or Steorts etÂ al. [2016]. The parameter of interest is the matching M=(M1,â€¦,Mn1)Msubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ‘›1\textbf{M}=(M_{1},\dots,M_{n_{1}}), while the data are x=(x1,â€¦,xn1)xsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘›1\textbf{x}=(x_{1},\dots,x_{n_{1}}) and y=(y1,â€¦,yn2)ysubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ‘›2\textbf{y}=(y_{1},\dots,y_{n_{2}}).

C.1 Prior distribution on the matching structure

We first specify a prior distribution for M, which is the unknown matching between {1,â€¦,n1}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›1\{1,\dots,n_{1}\} and {1,â€¦,n2}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›2\{1,\dots,n_{2}\}. First, we assume the prior distribution of M to be invariant with respect to permutations of {1,â€¦,n1}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›1\{1,\dots,n_{1}\} and {1,â€¦,n2}1â€¦subscriptğ‘›2\{1,\dots,n_{2}\}. This is a standard a priori assumption which is appropriate when the ordering of x and y is expected to carry no specific meaning. We then assume that the total number of entities in M (i.e.Â number of matched pairs plus number of singletons) follows a Poisson distribution a priori with unknown mean Î»ğœ†\lambda. Given the number of entities, each of them either generates two records (one in x and one in y) with probability pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„p_{match} or otherwise generates a single record (which is assigned either to x or to y with equal probability). Both Î»ğœ†\lambda and pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„p_{match} are treated as unknown hyperparameters. Such prior distribution for M can be seen as a simple, bipartite version of the more general priors for Bayesian record linkage discussed in Zanella etÂ al. [2016]. Note that also the sizes of x and y, which we denote by Nxsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥N_{x} and Nysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦N_{y} respectively, are random objects a priori to be conditioned on the observed values nxsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥n_{x} and nysubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¦n_{y}. The resulting prior distribution for M given Î»ğœ†\lambda and pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„p_{match} is

Pâ€‹(M|Î»,pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h)ğ‘ƒconditionalMğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„\displaystyle P(\textbf{M}|\lambda,p_{match}) =eâˆ’Î»â€‹Î»Nx+Nyâˆ’NmNx!â€‹Ny!â€‹(1âˆ’pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h2)Nx+Nyâˆ’2â€‹Nmâ€‹pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hNm,absentsuperscriptğ‘’ğœ†superscriptğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦superscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„2subscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„subscriptğ‘ğ‘š\displaystyle=\frac{e^{-\lambda}\lambda^{N_{x}+N_{y}-N_{m}}}{N_{x}!N_{y}!}\left(\frac{1-p_{match}}{2}\right)^{N_{x}+N_{y}-2N_{m}}p_{match}^{N_{m}}\,, (40)

where Nmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šN_{m} denotes the number of matches in M.

Derivation of (40).

First decompose the distribution of M as

The expression for Pâ€‹(Nm,Nx,Ny|Î»,pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥conditionalsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„P(N_{m},N_{x},N_{y}|\lambda,p_{match}) can be easily computed as

noting that, given Î»ğœ†\lambda and pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„p_{match}, the three random variables Nmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šN_{m}, Nxâˆ’Nmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘šN_{x}-N_{m} and Nyâˆ’Nmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘šN_{y}-N_{m} follow independent Poisson distributions with intensities Î»â€‹pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹hğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„\lambda p_{match} for the first and Î»â€‹(1âˆ’pmâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹câ€‹h2)ğœ†1subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘â„2\lambda\left(\frac{1-p_{match}}{2}\right) for the last two. C.2 Likelihood distribution

The distribution of (x,y)|MconditionalxyM(\textbf{x},\textbf{y})|\textbf{M} follows a discrete spike and slab model, also known as hit and miss model in the record linkage literature [Copas and Hilton, 1990]. C.4 Blocking implementation

In this context, sampling from GB, LB and HB has a computational cost that grows with nxsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥n_{x} and nysubscriptğ‘›ğ‘¦n_{y}. When the latter terms are too large, it is more efficient to apply informed schemes to sub-blocks of indices (see discussion in Section 6.4). In Section 7 we used the following block-wise implementation:

  1. 1.

    choose a subset of indices IâŠ‚{1,â€¦,nx}ğ¼1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥I\subset\{1,\dots,n_{x}\} and a subset JâŠ‚{1,â€¦,ny}ğ½1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¦J\subset\{1,\dots,n_{y}\} (details below)

  2. 2.

    remove the indices iâˆˆIğ‘–ğ¼i\in I that are matched with some jâˆ‰Jğ‘—ğ½j\notin J and, similarly, remove the indices jâˆˆJğ‘—ğ½j\in J that are matched with some iâˆ‰Iğ‘–ğ¼i\notin I

  3. 3.

    update the components (Mi)iâˆˆIsubscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ¼(M_{i})_{i\in I} by performing kğ‘˜k iterations of the MCMC kernel under consideration restricting the proposal of couples (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) to IÃ—JâŠ†{1,â€¦,nx}Ã—{1,â€¦,ny}ğ¼ğ½1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¦I\times J\subseteq\{1,\dots,n_{x}\}\times\{1,\dots,n_{y}\}.

Step 2 is needed to avoid moves that would involve indices outside IÃ—Jğ¼ğ½I\times J. It is easy to check that, if the MCMC used on the IÃ—Jğ¼ğ½I\times J subspace is invariant with respect to âˆiâˆˆIwiâ€‹Misubscriptproductğ‘–ğ¼subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–\prod_{i\in I}w_{iM_{i}}, then the whole chain is invariant with respect to âˆi=1nxwiâ€‹Misuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–\prod_{i=1}^{n_{x}}w_{iM_{i}}. There are many valid ways to choose the subsets Iğ¼I and Jğ½J in Step 1 (both randomly and deterministically). In our implementation in Section 7 we set the size of Iğ¼I and Jğ½J to 300. In order to favour couples having a non-negligible probability of being matched we alternated a uniformly at random selection of Iğ¼I and Jğ½J (which ensures irreducibility) with the following procedure: sample an index i0âˆˆ{1,â€¦,nx}subscriptğ‘–01â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¥i_{0}\in\{1,\dots,n_{x}\} and three features {s1,s2,s3}âŠ†{1,â€¦,â„“}subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 31â€¦â„“\{s_{1},s_{2},s_{3}\}\subseteq\{1,\dots,\ell\} uniformly at random; define Iğ¼I and Jğ½J as the set of iğ‘–iâ€™s and jğ‘—jâ€™s such that xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} and yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j} respectively agree with xi0subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–0x_{i_{0}} on the three selected features; if the size of Iğ¼I or Jğ½J exceeds 300, reduce it to 300 with uniform at random subsampling. We claim no optimality for the latter procedure and defer the detailed study of optimal block-wise implementations to further work (see Section 8).
